item.title: Download National Water Model (NWM) Data from Google Cloud Using Gsutil
item.description: The National Water Model (NWM) is a hydrologic modelling framework that simulates observed streamflow and complements official National Weather Service (NWS) river forecasts across the U.S., particularly produces guidance at locations that has no traditional river forecast. In the past, it is very difficult to access any NOAA archives. However, thanks to the NOAA Open Data Dissemination (NODD) program, a great number of NOAA data are now online cooperating with Amazon Web Services, Google, and Microsoft Azure.

item.title: The expression between ancient and modern
item.description: Today, in the hula class, kumu (hula instructor) answered one of my question bothering me long time while dancing hula - the expression. Hula can be classified into two category. Hula kahiko is the older and more traditional form of hula. Hula kahiko is danced to chants in Hawaiian. The instruments can be drums, ipu (gourd), etc. The movement is more basic, and facial expressions are more ritualistic. Whereas, modern hula, hula ʻauana, is softer and melodious with modern instruments such as ukuleles and guitars.

item.title: 23 Unsolved Hydrology Problems
item.description: Once a while, hydrologist gathered and discussed what the important hydrology questions that are not solved yet. Recently, Blöschl et al. (2019) spent more than a year to survey and conclude 23 unsolved hydrology problems. I really appreciate their work - it’s always to know where we are, what the status is, and what our goals are in the community. The problems have been classified into 6 groups - “The variability and change”, “Space variability and scaling”, “Variability of extreme”, “Interfaces in hydrology”, “Measurements and data”, “Modeling methods”, and “Interfaces with society”.

item.title: [Current Project] Characterizing natural flow regime of Hawaiian forest watersheds and its implication on downstream water availability
item.description: PI: Dr. Yinphan Tsang This project proposes to strategically characterize the natural flow regime of forest watersheds, the water resources protected by Hawai’i natural forests. This project proposes to support and train students and research assistants to perform various hydrological analyses to understand and reconstruct the natural flow regime of forested watersheds. The objectives of this study include: Examine types of forest watersheds and their typical streamflow response to precipitation, and describe their natural flow regime When data available, perform hydrologic analyses and/or modeling to address or simulate stream flow dynamics of the forest watersheds This project will gather preliminary data and ultimately applying to large federal agency proposals.

item.title: [Current Project] Characterizing the water availability and nutrient transport of Hawaii’s watersheds and its implication to downstream agriculture and coastal environment
item.description: PI: Dr. Yinphan Tsang This project proposes to characterize the water availability and quality of watersheds in Hawaii. This project proposes to support and train students and research assistants to survey the water quality and quantity and to perform hydrologic analyses. The objectives of this study include: Research and document the current status of water availability and nutrient loading in watersheds of Hawaii. Describe the nutrient loading, transport, and nutrient dynamic in Hawaii’s watersheds.

item.title: [Current Project] Deriving a sub-daily gridded rainfall dataset by combining rain gauge networks and weather radar in Hawaiʻi
item.description: (This is the second topic of my Ph.D. dissertation.) Current status: Concluded that the NEXRAD LEVEL III rainfall data won’e be included, and now testing different merging methods. Goals This study seeks a high spatial- and temporal-resolution of rainfall data that can be applied to research of extreme rainfall and streamflow events. Four steps are listed to achieve the goal: 1) collect data, select events and evaluate the rainfall product for Oʻahu; 2) compare existed merging methods with the selected events; 3) adjust the method based on local characteristics; 4) develop a framework and extend to the longer period (2014 – 2018) and maybe other islands.

item.title: Reanalysis vs. Observation
item.description: As a hydrological modeler, meteorological forcing is always crucial and challenging. Although I’ve heard re-analysis for a quite long time, I’ve never really tried to understand it till now. All I knew was that reanalysis is combining observation and model to produce gridded, 3-dimensional atmospheric data. I found a BAMS essay by Wendy S. Parker (September 2016): REANALYSES AND OBSERVATIONS - What’s the Difference?. My idea of reanalysis wasn’t too far, yet I was surprised that the re-analysis is not too different from observation except that we have less understanding of accuracy and uncertainty in re-analysis than observation.

item.title: How to build a staff plate in a mountainous stream? (part I)
item.description: Why do we need a staff plate? We need staff plate for knowing the stage (water height) while we’re measuring streamflow to build rating curve - a relationship between discharge and stage that allows us to know discharge by only stage. Why do we need to have a staff plate if we have other continuous stage sensors (i.e. pressure transducer) already? A staff plate is a datum that it won’t shift, so it’s a solid reference for the streamflow.

item.title: Water Escaping from a Small Watershed
item.description: Well, the title of this paper is “Partial Area Contributions to Storm Runoff in a Small New England Watershed” by Dunne and Black (1970), but Dunne used a lot of “water escaping” or “water escaped” in the article. item.title: Spatialized Flash Flood Guidance (SFFG)
item.description: Douinot et al. (2016) indicate that the FFG method significantly overestimates the intensity necessary to exceed the threshold flow for high intensity events in three catchments in France. They show the importance of the rainfall spatial variability in the estimating the rainfall intensity threshold for the flash flood forecasting. They proposed a Spatialized FFG (SFFG), a modified FFG with considering rainfall spatial characteristics. It has better estimations than the FFG in the high rainfall intensity cases.
